author: Sheersh Kapoor
title: Solar costs in India to rise as China cuts rebates, but the future appears bright
text:
3 Min Read
China’s decision to reduce export rebates on solar modules and components, effective 1 December, is set to increase electricity tariffs in India, creating short-term challenges but potentially paving the way for long-term benefits.
The rebate for modules will drop from 13% to 9%, while ancillary components like aluminium and copper wires will lose rebates entirely.
“The change in rebate from 13% to 9% would result in an increase in price at the module level by about 2–4 cents per watt-peak. For every one cent increase in module prices, tariffs are expected to rise by 6–7 paise, leading to an overall increase of 12–28 paise per unit of electricity," Sabyasachi Majumdar, Senior Director at CARE Ratings, explained.
This price hike will also affect existing contracts. “For contracts where a portion of modules arrive after December 1, the additional cost burden due to reduced rebates will likely be passed on by Chinese manufacturers, raising electricity generation costs for Indian developers," Saurabh Agarwal, Tax Partner at EY India, added.
Dependency on China continues
India remains heavily dependent on China for solar cells, with an 80% reliance that is unlikely to decrease before 2027, when domestic capacities are expected to stabilise. Majumdar noted: “While module production is becoming largely domestic, our dependency on China for upstream components like wafers and polysilicon will persist for years.”
Despite short-term difficulties, experts see a silver lining for Indian manufacturers. The rising cost of Chinese exports could enhance India’s global competitiveness. Agarwal remarked: “This aligns with India’s Atmanirbhar Bharat initiative, indirectly making Indian manufacturers more competitive as Chinese exports become costlier.”
India’s solar exports have already seen remarkable growth. According to a recent JMK Research report, Indian PV module exports surged by over 23 times between FY2022 and FY2024. This growth positions India as a reliable alternative to Southeast Asian manufacturers, particularly as the US imposes strict tariffs on Chinese imports.
Balancing domestic and export markets
However, domestic supply remains under pressure. Module production is expected to reach 28GW by FY2025, falling short of the 30GW required to meet India’s renewable energy goals.
Majumdar warned: “Balancing export growth and domestic demand is critical. Small-scale projects like rooftop solar, which have smaller order sizes, risk delays due to the supply-demand gap.”
The government is promoting localised production of wafers and ingots to mitigate dependency on imports. Experts believe long-term self-sufficiency will require sustained investments and targeted policies.
Agarwal emphasised: “The measures taken by China indirectly support India’s ambitions to become a global solar hub, but ensuring adequate domestic supply remains a pressing priority.”
The rebate for modules will drop from 13% to 9%, while ancillary components like aluminium and copper wires will lose rebates entirely.
“The change in rebate from 13% to 9% would result in an increase in price at the module level by about 2–4 cents per watt-peak. For every one cent increase in module prices, tariffs are expected to rise by 6–7 paise, leading to an overall increase of 12–28 paise per unit of electricity," Sabyasachi Majumdar, Senior Director at CARE Ratings, explained.
This price hike will also affect existing contracts. “For contracts where a portion of modules arrive after December 1, the additional cost burden due to reduced rebates will likely be passed on by Chinese manufacturers, raising electricity generation costs for Indian developers," Saurabh Agarwal, Tax Partner at EY India, added.

author: NewsBreak Original
title: Zodiac killer ‘victim’ nurse last seen walking with blonde man near her home is identified after 37 years
text: A MISSING person who is believed to be connected to the Zodiac killer has been identified after almost 40 years. The Placer County Sheriff’s Office has announced that they were able to identify the remains of Donna Lass who went missing in 1971. Lass's skull was found on Highway 20 near the Sierra Nevada mountains In 1986. However, it was revealed that there was no ways to identify her at the time, leading to the skull being preserved until coroners were able to get access to more advanced technology, according to recent press release. Placer County Sheriff’s Office along with the Placer County District Attorney’s Office had decided to work together to create a cold case team, which would lead to their shocking discovery. The team was able to send the skull to the California Department of Justice Bureau of Forensic Services, where they were able to identify the DNA from a sample due to Lass's other family members. "We are extremely grateful that this team effort was able to bring closure to the Lass family and are hopeful that cold case detectives can continue to make advances in these cases," the sheriff explained in the recent press release. At the time of her disappearance, she was 25 years old and just moved into her apartment in South Lake Tahoe, according to a news article shared by the police. She was last seen walking with a blond man who had not been identified. After she vanished police found her car, clothes, and bank account information. There has been speculation that Lass's disappearance had been connected to the Zodiac killer for years. In 1971, the San Francisco Chronicle received a strange postcard that had a symbol resembling the signature of the Zodiac Killer. The card had phrases such as “Sierra Club,” “Sought victim 12” and "peek through the pines," and the words "around in the snow," written upside down, The Sacramento Bee reported. This has led many to believe that Lass could have been murdered by the prolific killer, however authorites have not found proof of that just yet. As of now there is still a lot of unanswered questions surrounding the missing nurse's death. "It hasn’t been proven to be a homicide at this point, but we’re obviously treating it that way,” South Lake Tahoe Police Chief David Stevenson told NBC affiliate KCRA .

organizations.name: california department of justice bureau of forensic services

author: Technavio
title: Crop Protection Chemicals Market size is set to grow by USD 23.3 billion from 2024-2028, Increasing use of herbicides boost the market, Technavio
text:
NEW YORK , July 4, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- The global crop protection chemicals market size is estimated to grow by USD 23.3 billion from 2024-2028, according to Technavio. The market is estimated to grow at a CAGR of 3.21% during the forecast period. Increasing use of herbicides is driving market growth, with a trend towards implementation of integrated pest management (IPM) as new method of crop protection. However, organic farming as substitutes poses a challenge. Key market players include American Vanguard Corp., BASF SE, Bayer AG, Bharat Rasayan Ltd., BioWorks Inc., Chr Hansen Holding AS, Coromandel International Ltd., Corteva Inc., Dhanuka Agritech Ltd., Dow Chemical Co., DuPont de Nemours Inc., FMC Corp., Nufarm Ltd., Rotam CropSciences Ltd., Sumitomo Chemical Co. Ltd., Syngenta Crop Protection AG, Tata Chemicals Ltd., The Indogulf CropSciences Ltd., UPL Ltd., and Verdesian Life Sciences LLC.
Continue Reading
Technavio has announced its latest market research report titled Global crop protection chemicals market 2024-2028 Get a detailed analysis on regions, market segments, customer landscape, and companies- View the snapshot of this report

Ltd., Syngenta Crop Protection AG, Tata Chemicals Ltd., The Indogulf CropSciences Ltd., UPL Ltd., and Verdesian Life Sciences LLC
Market Driver
The agricultural industry faces significant challenges with pests causing losses of 11-35% in crop production, accounting for nearly one-third of production costs. Traditional pesticides have been a primary solution, but concerns over pest resistance and environmental and health risks have led to their decreased use. Integrated Pest Management (IPM) offers an alternative strategy. IPM is a proactive approach that combines various control methods, including inspection, monitoring, reporting, and selective pesticide application. By creating an inhospitable environment for pests through systemic resistance and proper operation design, IPM reduces the need for excessive pesticide use. Innovations in IPM techniques and technologies are anticipated to drive the growth of the global crop protection chemicals market during the forecast period.
The global crop protection chemicals market is a significant sector in agriculture, providing solutions for invasive pests and emerging diseases in various crops. With a focus on global agriculture, there is a growing demand for effective chemical solutions to ensure crop yields for staple foods like Cereal and Grains, Fruits and Vegetables, Oilseed and Pulses. However, stringent regulations and pesticide registration requirements have led to a shift towards biologicals, biopesticides, and natural alternatives. The market includes Synthetic and Natural crop protection chemicals, with Herbicides, Insecticides, and Fungicides being key segments. Consumer food preferences and environmental impact are driving the use of eco-friendly alternatives. Biotechnology and microbiology offer environmental benefits, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and tillage. Key players include agribusiness companies and small-scale manufacturers producing chemicals for Foliar Spray, Seed Treatment, and Soil Treatment. Some commonly used chemicals are Glyphosates, Difenoconazole, Imidacloprids, and Bifenthrin. The Herbicides segment dominates the market, especially in Cereals and oilseeds, with Rice cultivation being a significant application. Despite the benefits, concerns over pesticide residue and health effects persist. Malnutrition and food insecurity highlight the importance of healthy diets and sustainable food systems. The market's future lies in balancing crop protection with environmental impact and consumer preferences.
Research report provides comprehensive data on impact of trend. For more details- Download a Sample Report
Market Challenges
Organic farming is a method of cultivating crops without the use of synthetic pesticides, fertilizers, antibiotics, and genetically modified organisms. This approach promotes a sustainable and harmless environment through practices like crop rotation, cover crops, and balanced relationships between host and predator. Organic farming also recycles nutrients back into the soil through organic residues and composted manure. Organic crops have higher levels of antioxidants, such as polyphenolics, which reduce the risk of chronic diseases. These crops also have lower levels of toxic metals and minerals, such as cadmium, lead, and mercury, as well as lower concentrations of nitrogen, nitrate, and nitrite. Additionally, organic crops have fourfold less pesticide residue than conventional crops. The health-conscious consumer trend is driving the shift towards organic farming, leading to less use of agrochemicals. However, the increasing awareness of the benefits of organic farming may negatively impact the growth of the global crop protection chemicals market during the forecast period. The permitted substances list for organic farming approves certain substances to be used as pesticides, but the overall use is significantly reduced compared to conventional farming. The global Crop Protection Chemicals market faces challenges in various sectors including Fruits and Vegetables, Oilseed and Pulses. Foliar Spray, Seed Treatment, and Soil Treatment are essential methods for protecting crops. Herbicides, Insecticides, and Fungicides are key product types. Malnutrition and food insecurity call for healthy diets and robust Food Systems. However, pesticide residue and concerns over chemicals like Glyphosates, Difenoconazole, Imidacloprids, and Bifenthrin pose risks. Biotechnology and Microbiology offer environmental benefits, but regulatory pressures loom. Pesticide use and greenhouse gas emissions are under scrutiny. Tillage practices and Herbicides in Cereals and oilseeds, Rice cultivation, and small scale manufacturers face pressure from agribusiness companies. Formulation technologies like nanotechnology and encapsulation techniques are innovating, while regulatory pressures, precision agriculture technologies, and GPS-guided equipment, drones, and sensors shape the future. For more insights on driver and challenges - Request a sample report!
Segment Overview
This crop protection chemicals market report extensively covers market segmentation by
Application 1.1 Cereals and grains 1.2 Oilseeds and pulses 1.3 Fruits and vegetables 1.4 Turfs and others Type 2.1 Herbicides 2.2 Insecticides 2.3 Fungicides 2.4 Rodenticides and others Geography 3.1 APAC 3.2 South America 3.3 Europe 3.4 North America 3.5 Middle East and Africa 1.1 Cereals and grains- The global crop protection chemicals market is a significant industry that provides essential solutions for farmers to protect their crops from pests and diseases. These chemicals enhance agricultural productivity and ensure food security. Key players in this market include BASF SE, Syngenta AG, and Corteva Agriscience. They invest in research and development to introduce innovative products and expand their market reach. The market's growth is driven by increasing demand for food due to population growth and the need for higher crop yields. Regulations and environmental concerns, however, pose challenges to market expansion.
For more information on market segmentation with geographical analysis including forecast (2024-2028) and historic data (2017-2021) - Download a Sample Report
Research Analysis
The global crop protection chemicals market plays a crucial role in ensuring food security and addressing challenges posed by invasive pests and emerging diseases in agriculture. Chemical solutions, including herbicides, insecticides, and fungicides, help protect crops from damage and enhance yields. However, stringent regulations and pesticide registration requirements aim to mitigate the environmental impact and consumer concerns over pesticide residue. Malnutrition and food insecurity continue to be significant issues, making it essential to maintain healthy diets and sustainable food systems. Seed and soil treatments are essential tools in modern agriculture, with crop protection chemicals playing a vital role. Biotechnology and microbiology offer environmental benefits by providing alternative solutions to traditional pesticides. Key issues include the environmental impact of chemical use, consumer food preferences, and the role of pesticides in food systems. Glyphosates, Difenoconazole, Imidacloprids, and Bifenthrin are among the commonly used crop protection chemicals. The market continues to evolve, with a focus on reducing the use of pesticides and exploring new, innovative solutions.
Market Research Overview
The global crop protection chemicals market is a significant sector in the agriculture industry, providing chemical solutions to combat invasive pests and emerging diseases that threaten global food production. With the increasing focus on global agriculture to feed a growing population, the demand for crop protection chemicals is on the rise. However, stringent regulations and pesticide registration requirements, along with consumer food preferences for healthy diets and minimizing environmental impact, present challenges for the market. Crop protection chemicals include herbicides, insecticides, and fungicides, used in various forms such as foliar spray, seed treatment, and soil treatment. The market caters to staple foods like cereals and grains, fruits and vegetables, oilseed and pulses, and luxury crops. The use of biologicals, biopesticides, synthetic, and natural solutions continues to evolve, with biotechnology and microbiology playing a significant role. The market faces regulatory pressures due to concerns over pesticide residue, with glyphosates, Difenoconazole, Imidacloprids, and Bifenthrin being commonly used chemicals. The environmental impact of crop protection chemicals is also under scrutiny, with concerns over greenhouse gas emissions, tillage practices, and the use of herbicides. Small-scale manufacturers and agribusiness companies operate in the market, utilizing formulation technologies like nanotechnology and encapsulation techniques to improve efficacy and reduce environmental impact. Precision agriculture technologies, including GPS-guided equipment, drones, and sensors, are transforming the way crop protection chemicals are applied, increasing efficiency and reducing waste.

author: @UnioneSarda
title: Navi e aerei italiani contro gli Houthi in Mar Rosso - L'Unione Sarda.it
text:
Roma. Dall’Italia una nave e anche assetti aerei “spia” per la missione europea Aspides nel Mar Rosso, che avrà a Larissa in Grecia il quartier generale. L’indicazione l’ha fornita nell’informativa alle commissioni Difesa di Camera e Senato, il ministro Guido Crosetto, reduce dalla riunione di mercoledì con i suoi colleghi europei a Bruxelles. Il ministro ha ricordato la pericolosità degli Houthi, che negli ultimi due mesi hanno sferrato oltre 30 attacchi contro mercantili e che per capacità militari «valgono 10 volte Hamas», come dimostra il missile lanciato contro una nave al largo dello Yemen l’altra sera.
Il fronte del Mar Rosso è più caldo che mai. E l’Europa si appresta a varare Aspides ma, ha detto Crosetto, «auspichiamo la partecipazione di Paesi arabi moderati che volessero unirsi a questo sforzo collettivo di sicurezza e anche dell’India». Le navi militari europee, ha spiegato, faranno deterrenza e proteggeranno il traffico marittimo «mantenendo un coordinamento con l’altra missione Ue Atalanta, con cui Aspides condividerà parte dell’area, pur con distinzione di compiti, e con Prosperity Guardian», la missione angloamericana che, a differenza di quella Ue, bombarda le postazioni Houthi in Yemen. «Per ora - ha detto - gli assetti europei comprenderanno un minimo di tre unità navali, supporto intelligence e logistico, capacità di Early Warning aereo, protezione cyber, supporto satellitare e Comunicazione strategica». L’Italia concorrerà con «almeno una nave nel Mar Rosso per 12 mesi e stiamo valutando anche la possibilità di fornire assetti aerei con capacità di sorveglianza e raccolta dati».

author: Mike Heuer Sports News - UPI.com
title: 15-year-old New Zealander becomes youngest to break 4-minute mile mark
text:
Sports
15-year-old New Zealander becomes youngest to break 4-minute mile mark
March 19 (UPI) -- New Zealander Sam Ruthe, 15, became the world's youngest person to break the four-minute mile barrier with a time of 3:58.35 at Go Media Stadium in Auckland, N.Z., Wednesday evening.
Ruthe placed second in the rain-soaked race won by Olympian Sam Tanner and finished ahead of Ben Wall, who also broke the four-minute mark with a time of 3:59 to finish third, The New Zealand Herald reported.
Tanner posted a time of 3:58.29 while winning the race, the BBC reported.
"This was probably my favorite goal I've reached," Ruthe told media afterward.
"Definitely enjoyed this one the most with all the people here supporting me," he said. "It was absolutely magical to cross with my training partner Sam. One of the nicest feelings ever."
Ruthe is a middle-distance runner and already broke several records this year, including becoming New Zealand's youngest senior national champion while setting a world record time for his age in a 3,000-meters race in February.
He won the 3,000-meters title during the New Zealand Track and Field Championships with a time of 7:56.18, CNN reported.
Ruthe also tied Tanner for first place to win a share of the senior national championship in a 1,500-meters race in March.
Ruthe's world-record mile run was more than three seconds faster than his prior best of 4:01.72, which he posted during the Cooks Classic in January.
Ruthe turns 16 in April, and his time in the mile on Wednesday also bested Tanner's prior under-20 and under-19 records of 3:58.41.
Britain's Roger Bannister was the first human to break the four-minute barrier in the mile in 1954.
Copyright 2025 UPI News Corporation. All Rights Reserved.
This story was originally published March 19, 2025 at 6:19 PM.
